data.text:
In August 2015 I hopped off a plane in Changsha and was introduced to China for the first time.

I‚Äôve spent the last three years learning about Chinese culture, making many Chinese (and foreign) friends, and traveling to some pretty incredible places. China has challenged me to step way outside my comfort zone, try some strange foods and drink lots of homemade rice wine, and explore small villages and big skyscraper cities alike.

Since August 2015 I‚Äôve taught English to university students, kindergartners, professors working on doctorates, nurses and doctors in hospitals, and primary students in rural country schools.

Between teaching, traveling, and navigating every day life here, I‚Äôve had some interesting, inspiring, and crazy experiences in China! Here are a few things I‚Äôve learned from the last 3 years.

1. China Is Actually Highly Developed and Globalized

Before I came to China I pictured lots of small villages and walking miles to find any foreign shops (this was a very dramatic scene in my mind!). China is actually very advanced in terms of technology, apps, transportation (Chinese high speed trains are the BOMB), and the quality of life you can have.

China has some of the tallest buildings, best bike sharing systems, and most convenient public transportation in the world. You can find McDonald‚Äôs and Starbucks around every corner, and you‚Äôre never far from giant malls with all kinds of International Brands (unless you‚Äôre living in a small city‚Ä¶then that‚Äôs another story.)

2. Learning Chinese Isn‚Äôt As Hard As I Thought

You always hear Chinese is the most difficult language, but actually learning to speak basic Chinese isn‚Äôt terribly hard! You‚Äôre constantly surrounded by the language and will pick up little things in daily interactions with people. It‚Äôs actually fun to practice and local people will respect your efforts! With that said, I‚Äôm no Chinese expert but speak enough to get by, and learning Chinese characters is a bit harder üòâ

3. Western and Eastern Cultures Have Different Values And That‚Äôs Okay

There are lots of differences between the East and West. China is more focused on the collective group than the individual, something I noticed especially as a teacher in the school environment.

Families might express love in different ways; instead of verbally speaking I love you, they might show it through actions. In a conversation about love and families, I asked my students if their parents say ‚ÄúI love you‚Äù to them. One student said, ‚ÄúNo, but they will remind me to wear my coat and bring an umbrella if it‚Äôs raining, and they‚Äôll ask me if I‚Äôve eaten. This is how they express their love.‚Äù

This also goes for the Chinese work environment. When you work with Chinese colleagues, you might have different mindsets about how to accomplish a task, and that‚Äôs just how different cultures (and people!) work. Sometimes it means you have think creatively to solve problems and work hard to make sure your communication is clear.

4. Chinese Social Media Is Bomb

China has its own social media apps ‚Äì the top app is Wechat and it‚Äôs amazing. Wechat is a lifeline in China‚Ä¶not just for me, or even other foreigners, but everyone in China. We use it to pay for bills, translate messages, add money to our phones, buy movie tickets, order taxis‚Ä¶the list goes on and on.

China also has their own Twitter (called Weibo) and many other fantastic apps. I‚Äôm currently obsessed with this Chinese app called Tik Tok where you can see funny Chinese video trends ‚Äì if you follow me on Instagram I‚Äôve started posting these videos on my stories. Which leads me to‚Ä¶

5. Chinese Music and Pop Culture are AWESOME

I never imagined I‚Äôd be listening to Chinese music and singing it at KTV, but there it is. I‚Äôm in love with a singer called Zhang Jie (never heard of him? I‚Äôll tell you all about how I fell in love with a Chinese pop star) and love finding new Chinese songs to listen to.

Chinese TV shows are also quite funny. I‚Äôve watched some TV shows, mostly dramatic rom-coms which are super popular (and nothing like American shows) and some reality shows (Chinese dating shows are the best!!)

6. Chinese People Will Stare And (Hopefully) You‚Äôll Get Used To It

As a foreigner coming to a country where the majority of the population is Han Chinese, you‚Äôre going to stick out and be noticed.

I‚Äôve never had so many eyes on me before coming to China. Be it teaching, performing in talent shows, or just walking home from the grocery store or gym, I‚Äôm constantly in the limelight.

In Hengyang, the first city I lived in, the total foreigner population was less than 100. Many people had never seen a foreigner before! Lots of people would sneak photos of me on the bus, peek into my shopping cart to see what the ‚Äúforeigner‚Äù buys, or ask for a photo together. People aren‚Äôt intentionally trying to be rude or nosy, but seeing a foreigner is a novelty.

Even kids will walk straight up to you and take your photo.

Now that I live in Beijing, I experience this much less than when I lived in a smaller city, but it still happens when I go to touristy areas like Wangfujing Street or the Summer Palace where other Chinese tourists from other cities might be.

7. You Have To Be More Assertive

I‚Äôm not generally a very assertive person ‚Äì I ‚Äòm pretty non-confrontational, and if you knocked into me on the street I would probably apologize to you.

This doesn‚Äôt really fly in China ‚Äì if you don‚Äôt get thicker skin here, China will chew you up and spit you out. I had to learn that if I needed help at the store or wanted to get the waiter‚Äôs attention at a restaurant I had to be more loud and follow what other Chinese people do.

Now I don‚Äôt hesitate ‚Äì I‚Äôll squeeze my way onto a crowded bus and loudly yell ‚ÄúFuwuyuan!‚Äù in a restaurant, because that‚Äôs how you do it here.

*Note there is a difference between being assertive and being rude!

8. Patience and Flexibility Go A Long Way

On the other hand, there are times when you need to be patient. There are many cultural differences between China and the U.S. You have to handle a variety of situations, whether it is electricity shutting off, negotiating contracts and getting a work visa, or opening a new bank account and trying to buy train tickets. Lots of times people won‚Äôt speak English, or China has a different system for doing things. (Why can‚Äôt I transfer my money home like normal? It‚Äôs 2018!)

Flexibility and patience will take you far in China.

9. Chinese People Are Super Friendly And Hospitable

I have met some of the kindest and warmest people here, and I know I‚Äôm not alone!

Between my students, coworkers, Chinese friends, and even strangers, so many people have been so friendly and helpful. People have invited me out to dinner, helped me translate, answered my calls at all times when I needed help, and gave me advice and assistance with transitioning to new cities. The list goes on and on. Chinese people have gone above and beyond in helping me.

The couple I rented an apartment from in Guangzhou were incredibly kind and helpful! When a foreigner rents an apartment in China, it‚Äôs a bit more of a hassle ‚Äì but they made it incredibly easy for me, took me to dinner several times, and brought me housewarming gifts when I moved in!

Lots of people have a negative idea about traveling to China and interacting with local people, but just like anywhere you travel in the world there will be people who try to take advantage of you or leave you with a bad experience. I promise if you invest some time in China and stay open to the experiences here you‚Äôll be rewarded with kindness and open arms.

10. You Have To Adapt To A Variety of Living/Traveling Conditions

Traveling in China isn‚Äôt always easy. Just navigating a new city with limited Chinese can be a challenge, and then you add in squatty potties and hard beds, and that will toughen you up and prepare you for travel anywhere.

This is one of the bathrooms at the university I used to work at:

Living in China will toughen you up, too. You‚Äôll learn to hang all your laundry up (they don‚Äôt use dryers in China). You‚Äôll side step the guy spitting on the street. Tune out the lady loudly yelling on her phone on the bus next to you. Won‚Äôt blink twice at the baby peeing on road (most of the time). You‚Äôll start drinking hot water and pick up other Chinese habits. I can use a squatty like a pro now. Hard beds are the usual. Bring it on! (But also a mattress topper is highly appreciated.)

11. Meiyou Weishenme

My students used to say this to me after I asked them why they do things a certain way in China: ‚Äúmeiyou weishenme.‚Äù It‚Äôs rough translation is ‚Äúno why.‚Äù

Chinese people wear their coats until May even if it‚Äôs super hot outside because they have to follow the Lunar Calendar. Why? No why.

There are some Chinese traditions you just won‚Äôt understand and can‚Äôt be explained. Ask a Chinese friend about traditional rules a woman should follow during and after her pregnancy ‚Äì it will blow your mind.

12. Chinese Food Is The Best

There are 8 different cuisines to try in China and they all have their own signature dishes that will blow your mind. You‚Äôll get used to eating family-style and sharing lots of dishes. But be careful ‚Äì Chinese food can also can be very oily and salty, and you learn you can‚Äôt eat rice all the time if you‚Äôre trying to stay fit.

13. Respect the Culture

I‚Äôve met lots of foreigners in China, from just-arrived-in-China newbies up to 15-year expats and everything in between. There are so many interesting people from all over the world here! I really love hanging out with other foreigners, especially when they are open to new experiences, enjoy meeting Chinese people and learning Chinese, or just love living here as much as I do.

I‚Äôve met a few foreigners, however, who are extremely rude to Chinese people, be it in restaurants or taxis or even meeting friends I‚Äôve introduced them to. Even if there is a frustrating situation or you don‚Äôt understand everything about Chinese culture, there‚Äôs no need to be disrespectful to someone trying to help you. We live in China ‚Äì their country!

14. Being Independent Rocks

I‚Äôve faced lots of situations in China that I had to handle on my own. I came here right after I graduated from university, so there was a lot of ‚Äúlearning how to adult‚Äù going on, along with learning how to live in a foreign country. I‚Äôve had to learn how to do so many things on my own in China ‚Äì renting an apartment, arranging a new contract with schools, moving to new cities, etc. It‚Äôs not always easy, but I get a huge satisfaction out of accomplishing something on my own!

I also learned how to travel on my own ‚Äì I had never really traveled alone before China, but recently I‚Äôve traveled a lot on my own and found I absolutely love it. I enjoy the experience of planning a trip for myself, going wherever I want whenever I want, and meeting lots of local people or other travelers. I love the freedom and flexibility it gives me.

15. Say Yes to Everything & Embrace Spontaneity

China is going to throw some interesting situations at you. You‚Äôll get offered weird food. Strangers will invite you to their home ‚Äì or ask you to visit their hometown. You might be asked to join school performances or city events or be interviewed by a Chinese news station.

Some of my favorite memories have been times I just said yes to something I wasn‚Äôt sure about. Go on a date with a Chinese guy. Eat some duck blood. If Chinese people ask you to join their table at a bar, join in and learn to play the dice game (a great way to practice your Chinese numbers!). Heck, try some baijiu.

Safety first, of course! If you‚Äôre really feeling unsafe with a situation or person, use your best judgement. But don‚Äôt let your fear of the unfamiliar hold you back.

16. Your Students Will Change Your Life

I never imagined I‚Äôd be a university English teacher right after I graduated, but somehow it happened. Teaching 18 years olds when I was 22 not only built up my confidence, gave me lots of public speaking practice, and challenged me to be creative in lessons, but I also met some of the most interesting, caring, funny, and inspiring students. I built some relationships with students that now, even 3 years later, I still keep up with.

One of my students named Emily became one of my best friends in China!

My students have shown me a different side of China, something I wouldn‚Äôt have seen if I had just been passing through. I‚Äôve had countless hot pot parties, celebrated Christmas and lots of birthdays, hiked mountains, made dumplings, and traveled to different cities with many of my university students.

My students have also asked me some funny questions and opened up to me about their boyfriends and girlfriends, their family life, and their hopes and dreams for the future ‚Äì these relationships are so special to me.

The same goes for my kindergarten students ‚Äì it was a totally different experience teaching 3-5 year olds instead of teaching 18-20 year olds, but it was an equally amazing and unforgettable experience. Teaching them for a year melted my heart into a giant puddle on the floor and I still haven‚Äôt mopped it up.

Three Amazing Years

It‚Äôs impossible to fully sum up China! China is old temples and shiny shopping malls, 5000 years of history and a giant global market, old traditions mixed with new technology. For me, China is also the 600+ students I taught, it‚Äôs late night spicy Hunan BBQ after a night out, it‚Äôs traveling and making friends from all around the world.

China is nothing like what I expected ‚Äì to be honest the only way to understand China is to be here and experience it. Sometimes there are cultural differences and traditions you can‚Äôt figure out, but that‚Äôs part of what makes China so special.

The past 3 years have been so fantastic and I‚Äôm thankful to have experienced a small part of China! There‚Äôs still so much I don‚Äôt know about China ‚Äì but I‚Äôm looking forward to learning more and soaking in as much as I can.

If you‚Äôd like to receive future updates on what I‚Äôm doing in China, you can enter your email address at the bottom of this page if you‚Äôre on a mobile device, or on the sidebar if you‚Äôre on a computer! üôÇ
